pull.title: guix: Build for macOS using Clang only
pull.body:
This PR makes macOS builds Clang-only by switching the build compiler in depends to `clang` + `libc++`.

See: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/30206.

events.body: The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers. ### Code Coverage & Benchmarks For details see: https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/32764. ### Reviews See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process. | Type | Reviewers | | ---- | --------- | | Concept ACK | [w0xlt](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32764#pullrequestreview-2937295404) | If your review is incorrectly listed, please copy-paste <!--meta-tag:bot-skip--> into the comment that the bot should ignore. ### Conflicts Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones: * [#33775](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/33775) (guix: use GCC 14.3.0 over 13.3.0 by fanquake) * [#32162](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32162) (depends: Switch from multilib to platform-specific toolchains by hebasto) * [#25573](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25573) (guix: produce a `-static-pie` bitcoind by fanquake) If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first. ### LLM Linter (✨ experimental) Possible typos and grammar issues: - don't attempt -> not attempt (or "not to attempt") [Combines with "tells CMake to use ... and don't attempt" — grammatically should be "and not attempt" or "and not to attempt" for parallel infinitive construction] 2026-01-14
My Guix build matches @hebasto. No opinion on the change though.
Rebased to resolve a conflict with the merged bitcoin/bitcoin#33185.

Looks like this still using the GNU binutils for building native tools.

> Looks like this still using the GNU binutils for building native tools.

Should be fixed now.

verification.payload:
tree 4ffbf28b3ac2f6048f0764f32d1a1822e5b03fb5
parent 28f70c571bd45f1e7c29fbbdf61e8b318e198654
author Hennadii Stepanov <32963518+hebasto@users.noreply.github.com> 1765242007 +0000
committer Hennadii Stepanov <32963518+hebasto@users.noreply.github.com> 1768393837 +0000

guix: Define `libcxx-19` package

tree 349dbccd89d252bb97b3920fe7258b27eead1d04
parent 4814c5a7e609628b8033d4d9af5e0f591a27d4d3
author Hennadii Stepanov <32963518+hebasto@users.noreply.github.com> 1765242028 +0000
committer Hennadii Stepanov <32963518+hebasto@users.noreply.github.com> 1768393887 +0000

guix: Build for macOS using LLVM toolchain only

events.message: guix: Build for macOS using LLVM toolchain only

events.body: Rebased due to a conflict with the merged bitcoin/bitcoin#33775.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,6 +493,54 @@ inspecting signatures in Mach-O binaries.")
                    (("^install-others =.*$")
                     (string-append "install-others = " out "/etc/rpc\n")))))))))))))
 
+(define-public libcxx-18 ;; 18.1.8
comments.body: In 6ad54dce4a18b583f3c318ec078faa5a1412030a: Rather than adding a package here, I think we should wait until we next bump the time-machine (I've got a branch with some changes for this), where we'll likely use LLVM/Clang 19, and then can just use [`libcxx` (19)](https://codeberg.org/guix/guix/src/commit/a6c8217ee7e3c946bd83c84fd1e32587d4b0bc34/gnu/packages/llvm.scm#L1901). We could also upstream a `libcxx-20` now, which could then be used if we switch to LLVM/Clang 20.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,6 +493,54 @@ inspecting signatures in Mach-O binaries.")
                    (("^install-others =.*$")
                     (string-append "install-others = " out "/etc/rpc\n")))))))))))))
 
+(define-public libcxx-18 ;; 18.1.8
comments.body:
> In [6ad54dc](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/6ad54dce4a18b583f3c318ec078faa5a1412030a): Rather than adding a package here, I think we should wait until we next bump the time-machine (I've got a branch with some changes for this), where we'll likely use LLVM/Clang 19, and then can just use [`libcxx` (19)](https://codeberg.org/guix/guix/src/commit/a6c8217ee7e3c946bd83c84fd1e32587d4b0bc34/gnu/packages/llvm.scm#L1901).

That was my initial [approach](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/250327-qt6-clang/), as suggested in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/30206#issuecomment-2759053713. Unfortunately, there's an upstream issue in Guix affecting the `riscv64` host:
```
riscv64-linux-gnu-ld: relocation R_RISCV_RVC_JUMP against `__sigsetjmp' which may bind externally can not be used when making a shared object; recompile with -fPIC
...
build of /gnu/store/2drzypp2rgya0qcab3izkv9d8ib0kqvv-glibc-cross-riscv64-linux-gnu-2.31.drv failed
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,6 +493,54 @@ inspecting signatures in Mach-O binaries.")
                    (("^install-others =.*$")
                     (string-append "install-others = " out "/etc/rpc\n")))))))))))))
 
+(define-public libcxx-18 ;; 18.1.8
comments.body:
> Unfortunately, there's an upstream issue in Guix affecting the riscv64 host:

See #33185.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,6 +493,55 @@ inspecting signatures in Mach-O binaries.")
                    (("^install-others =.*$")
                     (string-append "install-others = " out "/etc/rpc\n")))))))))))))
 
+;; This can be dropped after commit 2877c75dc5db0dbf664fb6170d5754068e941d91.
comments.body:
> This can be dropped after commit 2877c75dc5db0dbf664fb6170d5754068e941d91.

Would be good for this to explain why (is libunwind causing build issues?). Could also mention that this is copy-pasted from Guix, and I assume the intention isn't to change it here, if we plan on dropping it?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -132,7 +148,16 @@ for p in "${PATHS[@]}"; do
 done
 
 # Disable Guix ld auto-rpath behavior
-export GUIX_LD_WRAPPER_DISABLE_RPATH=yes
+case "$HOST" in
+    *darwin*)
+        # The auto-rpath behavior is necessary for darwin builds as some native
comments.body:
> as some native  tools

If we are re-introducing this, I think we can be explicit about which tools. Can we just build them statically  to not need to do this?
